Comment: King's Pawn opening.
The caro-kann defense
Standard move grabbing the centre.
standard book move

The advance variation of the caro-kann (3. e5) is the most popular move here presently. My opponent chose 3. Nc3, the 2nd most popular move here. 3. Nc3 is a perfectly good attempt for white to fight for an advantage.
standard move
standard move
Nd7 is the modern variation. Former world champion Karpov played Nd7 frequently. The other main move is Bf5 (the classical variation). I play both variations. I don't really have a preference.
standard move
standard move. Black would like white to exchange Knights allowing his d7 knight to move to f6.

I was happy to see Bd3. It allows me to capture on e4 and bring the knight from d7 to f6 to threaten the bishop. I think 6. Ng3 might be better for white. White may be moving the same piece twice in the opening but its good here. It makes black's development difficult.
developing the light squared bishop to the most logical spot.

protecting the pawn. Bxf3 and pawn/queen capture allows black to capture d4, winning a pawn.

asking a question to the bishop. Where do you want to go?
Both retreat and capture I think is ok. I played Bh5 so not to give white the bishop pair.

This move stops black playing Nxg4 hxg4 Rxh1 winning material. At the time I thought the best move was g5. White would followup with Qc2 or Qe2, Bd2 and then 0-0-0. This may or may not be better than the actual game.
Move attacks b2 and renews Nxg4 (hxg4 Rxh1)
can't stop both threats. Needs to take.
